headline.main: From the South--The Yellow Fever at Saw Yabrah and Charleston--Steamboat Upset and Four Lives Lost--Dual Prevented.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Southern mail from new-Orleans and intermediate points as late as due is received. The Savannah Courier admits that yellow fever prevails as an epidemic in that city, and calls for the organization of ?? Howard Association and the publication of daily reports.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Independent Line steamship North Star, Captain WAMACK, arrived here yesterday, with 405 passengers, from Aspinwall. On her outward passage the North Star left New-York on the 5th, at 3 1/4 o'clock.
docs.snippet: The Independent Line steamship North Star, Captain WAMACK, arrived here yesterday, with 405 passengers, from Aspinwall. On her outward passage the North Star left New-York on the 5th, at 3 1/4 o'clock.

docs.lead_paragraph: Among the last received English newspapers, by the Asia, is one which contains the following brief announcement: "DIED.--On Aug. 8, in Gloucester road, Old Brompton, THOMAS CROFTON CROKER, Esq., aged 57."

headline.main: Further Foreign News by the Asia.; Trial of a Woman for the Mu??der of her Six Children--Plea of Insani??y. MURDER TRAIL.

docs.lead_paragraph: From the London Times. Mr. Justice ERLE, that whom a more intelligent and upright judge does not sit upon the English bench, must have been as much astonished as we were at the verdict of the jury upon the Ester murderess on Wednesday last. That ANNE BROUGH murdered her six children in the most pitiless and coldhlouded manner was a point upon which there was no dispute.

docs.lead_paragraph: NOTES OF TRAVEL OR RECOLLECTIONS OF MAJUNGA, ZANZIBAR. MUSCAT, ADEN, MOCHA, AND OTHER EASTERN PORTS. Salem. Published by GEO. CHEAMER. No author's name appears on the title page of this modest book; but JOSEPH B. F. OSGOOD takes out the copyright. It suits us very well. Our reader shall see how it suits him,--if extracts will suffice for that purpose.

docs.lead_paragraph: From the interior we have received a few additional exchanges, but find very little of interest. A few cases of yellow fever had occurred in Galveston. From Corpus Christi we learn that a few days after the Indians were repulsed by Capt. VAN BUREN, another party of the same Indians visited Major DURST'S Rancho, on the Presenas, and murdered five men, three Mexicans and two Americans, and killed and injured some of his stock.
